awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Tough polymer composite materials through iLAMB, or interlaminar modifications through master batching
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to help usher in a new age of material consumption. While metals have been used for hundreds of years, composites are fairly new but can withstand even more wear and tear than steel. This project is aimed to advance composites even further by making them last longer or shed more weight. This will enable engines to have better fuel efficiency, allow lighter prosthetics, or achieve dependable, durable composite automobile frames. MITO hopes to aid all of these industries with the introduction of competitive and proprietary resin modifying  nanoaddtives that enhance durability and toughness, reduce weight, and can be integrated into common composite manufacturing processes, including infusion molds and pre-pregs. With these potentials, it is estimated that this project could capture roughly 5% of the worldwide additive market currently worth $3.8 billion dollars, positioning material science to solve the composite industry's biggest problems with nano-sized solutions.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will scale up hybrid nano-fillers based on graphene oxide (GO) and polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (POSS) to kilogram quantities and produce nano-fillers that have reactive moieties that are exactly compatible and dispersible in various resins, which has never been attempted before. The Phase I project successfully met all the technical goals. MITO additives will be added to epoxy or vinyl ester or polyester matrices through a Master Batch process to enhance the interlaminar fracture toughness of composite by more than 70% at extremely low addition levels (~0.1 to 0.2% by weight) without any changes in current manufacturing processes. It is proposed to scale up the existing hybrid nano-fillers, develop novel hybrid nano-fillers with better compatibility with epoxy, vinyl ester and polyester resins by introducing matching reactive groups into the fillers and Master Batching so that interlaminar fracture toughness can be improved by more than 100%. Flexure, Impact and SENB fracture tests, and XRD as well as SEM characterization will be performed on the cured Master Batches and composites. Flexure, double cantilever beam fracture and tension tests will be performed on composite samples to optimize the nanofiller content and the Master Batching process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The scope of Phase II/IIB was to showcase commercial viabilty of novel hybird addtives by addressing technical challenges in scaling the chemical synthesis process, optimizing costs and supply chain elements and charactreizing the performance improvements of novel hybrid additives in fiber reinforced composites. The project was ultimately successful in scaling commercialzing the originally formulated ILAMB in three different product forms distributed to 150+ customers who are actively evaluating the material in their products or applications. As the outcome report summarizes, the broader impact of scaling and commercialzing these products is vast because of the products ablity to chemcially and physically bond in composite matrices.

 

During work with Wabash International to qualify iLAMB within their products via TECP funding, it was found that both 0.05%wt and 0.1%wt of iLAMB in the polyester used in their process was able to mechanically outperform their more expensive Vinylester system by up to 135% beyond the vinylester. This work was able to show that with a minimal amount of iLAMB, lighter and more efficient transportation systems can benefit from advanced composites. During this project, we learned from industry contacts that wind turbine blades suffer the same failure modes using the same polymer systems. These results with Wabash demonstrated that with the large increase in modulus, which correlates to increased fatigue longevity, wind turbine blades would be an excellent beneficiary of these property increases.

 

Alongside these iLAMB qualifications, it was conceptualized that if graphene oxide was able to interchange with graphene, lower costs were achievable. The technical challenge with this is that to utilize the iLAMB process, higher oxygen content is needed, hence the preference to use graphene oxide as a feedstock despite its higher cost. In Q4 of 2022, graphene based iLAMB was achieved with a graphene that had extremely low oxygen content. Based on Thermogravical analysis, graphene oxide based iLAMB has what is qualified as high residual silicon (the metric used to determine how much grafting was achieved). A graphene based iLAMB was able to achieve an acceptable residual silicon content to meet the standards we have established to denote a successful reaction. Studies are on-going to characterize performance in polymer composites as well as particle size range and morphology.

 

The scope of work during Phase II/IIB was to showcase various production improvements of iLAMB as well as supply qualification. This phase was able to prove that production optimization was achieved by producing more product that has not been achievable to date. At the start of Phase II, iLAMB was being made in 200 gram batches. As of late 2022, iLAMB is being manufactured in 25,000 gram batches at a more efficient pace than at the start of Phase II. During this optimization procedure, other graphene oxide suppliers were identified and sourced to evaluate the efficacy of their feedstock in the iLAMB process. What was found was that these feedstocks were not only more expensive at scale than what was already being used, but that the original graphene oxide supplier had a far superior and consistent feedstock. Other suppliers could not control critical parameters as they provided larger batches, which therefore affected the production of iLAMB. The various suppliers and feedstocks are evaluated from quality check processes developed during the grant that uses novel technology that is now being recommended by international ISO/ANSI standards for graphene and graphene oxide characterization. With these batches of scaled and affordable iLAMB, a universal appeal was generated for this product, ranging from sporting goods (i.e. snow sports, golf, fishing) to transportation, automotive, and aerospace applications, all of which are evaluating iLAMB in their various products and processes. This market traction led us to identify a common epoxy resin for use to create masterbatch carriers that are either diluted to desired concentrations or used at the 1%wt concentration that is supplied as is. To date, iLAMB has been masterbatched into 100 gallons of epoxy resin for use in various sport applications.

 

The iLAMB procedure was then used to attempt development of a different chemistry utilizing the same operating parameters, graphene oxide, and POSS particles to formulate an additive for methacrylate systems. The methacrylate-graphene oxide was achieved with an acceptable silicone residue content via Thermogravical analysis. One drawback that was seen was that with the formulation of a methacrylate-graphene oxide, it had to be kept rich in solvent (20%wt or more) to not form hard clumps that were unable to be recovered. Optimizations are still ongoing to solve this issue. With the market traction and adoption generated with iLAMB, its masterbatch product, and scalability of the technology, the company was able to go fundraise multiple millions of dollars from external corporate partners. These developments, fund raising activities and market traction led to the filing of a new patent that entered the world stage as of December 2022 (Patent WO2021257556A2).


Last Modified: 02/24/2023
Modified by: Haley M Keith
